comment.author: 21686909@N07
comment._content:
From Wikipedia:

Another dispute over American Indian government is its sovereignty versus that of the states. The federal U.S. government has always been the government that makes treaties with Indian tribes - not the states. Article 1, Section 8 of the Constitution states that “Congress shall have the power to regulate Commerce with foreign nations and among the several states, and with the Indian tribes”.[3] This determined that Indian tribes were separate from the federal or state governments and that the states did not have power to regulate commerce with the tribes, much less regulate the tribes. The states and tribal nations have clashed over many issues such as Indian gaming, fishing, and hunting. American Indians believed that they had treaties between their ancestors and the United States government, protecting their right to fish, while non-Indians believed the states were responsible for regulating commercial and sports fishing.[26] In the case Menominee Tribe v. United States in 1968, it was ruled that “the establishment of a reservation by treaty, statute or agreement includes an implied right of Indians to hunt and fish on that reservation free of regulation by the state”.[27] States have tried to extend their power over the tribes in many other instances, but federal government ruling has continuously ruled in favor of tribal sovereignty. A seminal court case was Worchester v. Georgia. Chief Justice Marshall found that “England had treated the tribes as sovereign and negotiated treaties of alliance with them. The United States followed suit, thus continuing the practice of recognizing tribal sovereignty. When the United States assumed the role of protector of the tribes, it neither denied nor destroyed their sovereignty.”[28] As determined in the Supreme Court case United States v. Nice (1916),[29] U.S. citizens are subject to all U.S. laws even if they also have tribal citizenship.

                                     - from "Tribal Sovereignty in the United States

comment.author: 98233978@N04
comment._content:
Indian reservations have always been considered independent of state governments, but that does not mean that they are independent sovereign nations equal in status with the United States, Belgium, Japan, or Argentina. They do not have a seat at the United Nations nor do they exchange ambassadors with foreign countries. Indian reservations are still subject to United States sovereignty, the land they sit on is U.S. territory. Indian tribes are sovereign in the same sense of the word as U.S. states are referred to as sovereign states. This is not the same sovereignty that nation states possess. Nation states have complete sovereignty over their land, this includes U.S. sovereignty over Indian reservations. Therefore the United States has the right of eminent domain over all tribal lands and has the legal right to seize that land for it's own use, provided that the tribes are given compensation. 

Once the "Native Americans" lost their sovereignty to the European colonial powers the ball-game was over. North America ceased to be their land, however unjust this might have been. No more unjust than Egypt being ruled by Arabs. The history of humanity has been one long list of injustices, but we can only deal with reality as it exists now, not as we wish things could have been or should have been. When the United States acquired its land from Britain, France, Spain, Mexico, and Russia the "injustice" that the European nations had committed against the "Native Americans" was simply an historical footnote.
